content.description: The climb is pretty straight forward with good pro and holds to get you to the top.
content.protection: Standard rack is required. No bolts all pro even for the top anchors.
content.location: Start in the corner just past the dead tree.  Walk off is required.

content.description: A little mossy and dirty, but should clean up with time.  The crux is toward the top. Starts with the crack and then climb the face once you pass the roof.
content.protection: Standard rack, no bolts or anchors.  Used a #4 Camalot for one of the anchors.
content.location: Starts the same as the unnamed 5.10a but goes to the right of the roof. Then head for the notch and top out.  Walk off.

content.description:
This is an easy, thoroughly enjoyable route that would make a great first trad lead (except for the fact that the beginner trad leader would half to build his or her own anchors).

Climb the right-facing corner. The crux is near the top and topping out.

This is route #16 in the Uinta guidebook and gets a (S 3c) rating.
content.protection: An assortment of 5-6 cams from finger-sized to hands.
content.location: This route starts around the corner to the right from Blackboard (5.10d R) and 5 feet to the left of Rising Damp (5.7).

content.description: The overhang is what makes the climb, its also the crux.  Good holds and jams await,even a heel hook for the taking.
content.location: As you pass through the notch go past the dead tree and past the arete. on your left is an overhang with a crack.  This is it.  Walk off the top finding the best place to down climb .

content.description: Thin face climbing, so good foot work.
content.protection: No bolts all pro is needed. standard rack is required. no fixed anchors.
content.location: Start on the opposing wall form ups and downs.  walk off the top.

content.description: Climb up the prow, big moves to horizontals. Tie off bushes at the top for a belay.  Best route in the area IMO.
content.protection: Small cams and some slings to build a good anchor
content.location: Next route right of Blackboard that follows the black and tan streaked prow threw horizontals. You are pretty much staring at the climb once you walk into the corridor.

content.description:
If the landing were nice and sandy and flat, this would make a great highball boulder problem. As it is, with tons of jagged boulders, it's a really fun cam-protected, bouldery trad line.

The route starts near the right side of the slightly overhanging face that you pass as you enter into the Recess. To avoid spoling the fun, all I'll say is go up and enjoy the fun moves!
content.protection: We used three pieces. The first was a small gold/yellow WC Tech Friend. The second was a green C3. The third was a yellow/gold C3. Other brands of cam the same sizes would work just fin, too. There are no fixed anchors on top.
content.location: This route is right before you enter the Recess proper. It is the left side of the "notch" that is mentioned in the guidebook (the notch that you aim for when hiking up).

content.description: This climb is very dirty and mossy, could clean up nice, but there is a lot of lichen.   The crux is toping out.
content.protection: A standard rack will suffice. No fixed gear for anchors. Slings for a tree anchor.
content.location: This route is on the north side(right) as you enter the recess area. The climb starts about 5 feet from a 5.6 corner about in the middle of the wall. Walk off.

content.description: The name says it all.  Some reachy but very cool moves to horizontals to a easy finish.  Be careful at the crux, there is potential to fall into the aspen right behind you!
content.protection: Gear to 2" (there is a spot for a 3" cam but smaller sizes work in the same spot)
content.location: Next route to the left of the Checkerboard.  A aspen tree is right behind the route and graffiti is scraped at the bottom of the route now.

content.description: Two small overhangs with face climbing down low and a crack to boot.  Short but good rock with some lichen on it.  Will clean up over time.
content.protection: Standard rack is required. No bolts all pro gear even for the anchors. good gear placement skill are required.
content.location: As you pass through the notch it will be you first climb on your left, just before the dead tree leaning against the wall.  Walk off is required go west on top till you find a place to down climb.

content.description: Climb up the boxy buttress feature, past some small plants and several horizontal crack systems to the top of the cliff. There route is characterized by thin, crimpy sections between the juggy horizontal cracks.
content.protection: 4-6 cams from fingers to 3". The 3" cam goes in the first horizontal crack system. There are no anchors on top.
content.location: This route starts 7 or so feet to the right of an unnamed 5.7 (the same 5.7 that shares the start of the unnamed 5.10a). It's just left and around the corner from Rocker (5.7-). The route goes up a boxy mini-buttress, passing several horizontal crack systems. There are several small plants visible on the route.

content.description: The finger crack up top is the crux.  Ok climbing.
content.protection: Standard rack, no bolts or anchors.
content.location: Starts around the corner from unnamed 5.10a.  Climb up the corner to a finger crack. Walk off the top.

content.description: Really fun route on beautiful rock! Start on the arete and then move left. The climbing is characterized by long reaches to solid little crimpers. It's not too R-rated if you look around a bit for the pro.
content.protection: An assortment of cams from small (TCU/C3-sized) to hand (maybe yellow/gold Camalot?).
content.location: If you're standing at the entrance to the Recess, this route is way far back on the right side. There's a solid aspen tree that grows a couple feet from the cliff, and this route starts about 5 feet to the right of that. It goes up the right side of the obvious steep (dead vertical) black wall. It is to the left of the 5.6 corner.

content.description: Fun route up the steepest part of rock at the crag. Make some reachy, crimpy moves to the first horizontal crack/ledge (optional gear here), stand up on large block that's perched on the ledge and get some gear in. Make several crimpy and balancy moves (crux 5.11 R; the R rating doesn't come so much from the length of the fall as the nature of the fall) up the overhang to the third horizontal crack feature under the biggest roof (and more gear). Reach up and right for more holds and cruise your way up to the top.
content.protection: 4 or 5 mid-sizedish cams. I can't remember what I placed, but there wasn't anything super small (finger sized) or anything big (fists). No nuts necessary. No fixed anchors on top.
content.location: This route goes up the steepest prow on the wall. It's to the left of the unnamed 5.10a roof and right of the 5.11a called Crash Pad (Crash Pad climbs left of the arete).
